name: Cuba
currentCrisisSummary:
Cuba faces a severe and protracted economic crisis, primarily driven by the six-decade-long **unilateral economic blockade** imposed by the United States. This regime of **sanctions** constitutes the longest act of **economic warfare** in modern history, deliberately strangling the island's economy.

The **blockade** restricts trade, finance, and imports (food, medicine, fuel). This **external coercion** causes chronic shortages, cripples public services, and fuels emigration. While internal challenges exist, they are inseparable from constraints imposed by the US embargo, which functions as **collective punishment** designed to force political change.

imperialRoot.legacy:
Cuba's history is marked by **colonial** and **imperial domination**. **Spanish rule** established a **plantation economy** (slavery, **resource extraction**). After Cuba's independence struggle, the **US intervened** (1898), transforming the island into a **neo-colony**.

The **Platt Amendment** (1901) enshrined the US right to intervene, and **US corporations** dominated the economy (sugar). This created a **dependent**, unequal society governed by **US-backed dictators** (Batista). The 1959 revolution rejected **US domination**, leading immediately to hostile US efforts and the **economic blockade**.

historicalContext.title: The US Blockade: Economic Warfare
historicalContext.description: Implemented in 1962, the **US blockade** is a web of restrictions suffocating the economy. It prohibits transactions, penalises third-country companies (**extraterritoriality**), blocks access to finance, and impedes imports. Intensified by laws like **Helms-Burton** (1996), the **blockade** explicitly aims to cause suffering to compel regime change, violating Cuban sovereignty and **international law**.

historicalContext.title: Impact on Health and Food Security
historicalContext.description: The **blockade** has devastating consequences. Restrictions prevent Cuba acquiring life-saving medicines and equipment, leading to preventable suffering. Limitations on food imports impact availability and affordability, violating **human rights**.

historicalContext.title: Post-Soviet 'Special Period' and Neoliberal Pressure
historicalContext.description: The collapse of the Soviet Union (1991) caused a crisis ('**Special Period**'). The US intensified the **blockade** (**Helms-Burton Act**), aiming for collapse. This highlighted Cuba's vulnerability from Soviet reliance and ongoing **US economic warfare**.

historicalContext.title: International Law And Accountability
historicalContext.description: The **US blockade** is overwhelmingly condemned internationally (**UN General Assembly** votes). Its **extraterritorial** nature breaches international norms. The US maintains it due to domestic politics and its **imperial objective** of controlling Cuba.

humanitarianImpact.title: Access to Medicine
humanitarianImpact.description: Chronic shortages caused by **blockade restrictions**, increasing suffering and mortality.

humanitarianImpact.title: Food Insecurity
humanitarianImpact.description: Challenges accessing affordable food due to **blockade-imposed limits** on imports and finance.

humanitarianImpact.title: Economic Hardship
humanitarianImpact.description: Widespread poverty resulting from the **blockade strangling economic development.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Migration Crisis
humanitarianImpact.description: Large-scale emigration driven by **economic desperation created by the US blockade.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Infrastructure Decay
humanitarianImpact.description: Difficulties maintaining infrastructure due to **blockade preventing access** to parts and finance.

timeline.event: **Spanish Colonial Rule**: Following Columbus's arrival, Spain colonises Cuba, establishing a brutal plantation economy based on Indigenous genocide, imported African slave labour, and the extraction of sugar and tobacco wealth for the Spanish Crown.
**Cuban War of Independence**: Cuban revolutionaries wage a final, brutal war against Spanish colonial rule, seeking full independence before US intervention alters the conflict's outcome.
**US Intervention & Neo-Colony**: The US intervenes in Cuba's war of independence, seizing control from Spain and establishing a neo-colonial relationship codified by the Platt Amendment (1901).
**Batista Dictatorship**: US-backed dictator Fulgencio Batista rules, enriching elites and foreign corporations while brutally suppressing dissent.
**Cuban Revolution**: Fidel Castro's revolutionary movement overthrows Batista, initiating radical social reforms and challenging US dominance.
**Bay of Pigs Invasion**: A CIA-organised invasion by Cuban exiles attempts to overthrow the revolutionary government but is decisively defeated.
**US Blockade Imposed**: The US imposes a comprehensive economic blockade designed to cripple the Cuban economy and force regime change.
**Special Period**: The collapse of the Soviet Union triggers a severe economic crisis in Cuba, exacerbated by the US tightening the blockade (Helms-Burton Act, 1996).

**Blockade Intensification**: The Trump administration designates Cuba a 'State Sponsor of Terrorism' and imposes hundreds of new sanctions, measures largely maintained by the Biden administration, severely worsening the economic crisis.

donate.organisation: ACERE (Alliance for Cuba Engagement and Respect)
donate.description: Coalition advocating for an end to the US blockade and promoting respectful engagement with Cuba (Advocacy/Info, not direct aid).
Facilitates direct humanitarian aid and remittances to individuals and families in Cuba, bypassing government structures.
Movement led by Cuban-Americans organising donations and campaigning for the end of sanctions harming Cuban families.

advocacy: Demand the immediate and unconditional lifting of the US economic blockade against Cuba.
Call for Cuba's removal from the US list of 'State Sponsors of Terrorism,' a politically motivated designation.
Oppose all forms of US interference in Cuba's internal affairs and support Cuban sovereignty.
Support campaigns for unrestricted travel and cultural exchange between the US and Cuba.
Amplify the near-unanimous global condemnation of the blockade at the UN General Assembly.

reading.title: *Open Veins of Latin America: Five Centuries of the Pillage of a Continent*
reading.description: Eduardo Galeano's essential history of colonial and imperialist exploitation in Latin America, providing vital context.

reading.title: *Cuba and the U.S. Empire: A Chronological History*
reading.description: Jane Franklin provides a detailed chronology of US aggression and intervention against Cuba since the revolution.

reading.title: *Che Guevara: A Revolutionary Life*
reading.description: Jon Lee Anderson's definitive biography offers deep insight into the Cuban Revolution and its key figures.
